Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para:
Let
$$(X, *, 0)$$
( X ,
∗ , 0 )
be a d-algebra and
$$\alpha , \beta $$
α , β
are endomorphisms on X. Motivated by some results on derivations,
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation in rings, and the generalizations of BCK and BCI-algebras, in this paper, we introduce the notion of
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivations on d-algebras, construct several examples and investigate some simple and important results.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: The study of derivations in rings though initiated long back, but got impetus only after Posner [11] who in 1957, established two very striking results on derivations in prime rings. BCI-algebra has been developed from BCI-logic on the similar way as Boolean algebra was developed from Boolean logic. Imai and Iseki in [3, 4], introduced two classes of abstract algebras BCK-algebras and BCI-algebras and have been extensively investigated by many researchers. They have shown that the class of BCI-algebra is a proper subclass of BCK-algebra.

In [9], the authors introduced the notion of d-algebras which is another useful generalization of BCK-algebras. They investigated several relations between d-algebras and BCK-algebras as well as some other interesting relations between d-algebras and oriented groups. In [9, 10] Jun et al., discussed ideal theory in d-algebras and introduced the notions of d-algebras, d-ideal and investigated some relations among them. Jun and Xin in [5], applied the notion of derivation in ring and near ring theory to BCI-algebras and they also introduced a new concept called a regular derivation in BCI-algebras. They investigated some of its properties, defined a d-invariant ideal and gave conditions for an ideal to be d-invariant. In non-commutative rings, the notion of derivations is extended to d-derivations, left derivations and central derivations.

Recently, several authors [1, 8] have studied
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivations in BCI-algebras and f-derivation on BCC-algebras [7]. Very recently, Kandaraj and Chandramouleeswaran [6] introduced the notion of left f-derivations of d-algebras and obtained some properties.

Motivated by the notion of
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation in the theory of rings, in this paper, we introduce the notion of
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivations on d-algebras and investigate related properties. We provide a condition for a
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation to be regular. We also introduce the concepts of a
$$d_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
d
( α , β )
-invariant
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation,
$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal and
$$\beta $$
β
-ideal and then we investigate their relations. Furthermore, we obtain some results on regular
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivations. Finally, we construct several examples and establish some more interesting results.

Section1.Heading: Preliminary results
Section1.Para: In this section, we recall some basic definitions and properties that will be needed in the sequel.

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 2.1
FormalPara.Para:
[9] A d-algebra is a non -empty set X with a constant 0 and a binary operation
$$*$$
∗
satisfying the following axioms:
(1)
$$x *x = 0$$
x
∗ x = 0
(2)
$$0 *x = 0$$
0
∗ x = 0
(3)
$$x *y = 0$$
x
∗ y = 0
and
$$y *x = 0 \Rightarrow x = y$$
y
∗ x = 0 ⇒ x = y
.

Section1.Para:
Properties In any d-algebra X, the following is holds for all
$$x, y,z\in X$$
x , y , z ∈ X
(1)
$$(x *y)*z =(x *z)*y$$
( x
∗ y )
∗ z = ( x
∗ z )
∗ y
(2)
$$0*(x *y)= (0*x)*(0*y)$$
0
∗ ( x
∗ y ) = ( 0
∗ x )
∗ ( 0
∗ y )
(3)
$$(x*(x*y))*y=0$$
( x
∗ ( x
∗ y ) )
∗ y = 0
(4)
$$x*(x*y)=y$$
x
∗ ( x
∗ y ) = y
.

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 2.2
FormalPara.Para:
[9] Let S be a non empty subset of a d-algebra X then S is called subalgebra of X if
$$x *y \in S$$
x
∗ y ∈ S
for all
$$x, y \in S$$
x , y ∈ S
.

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 2.3
FormalPara.Para:
[2] Let X be a d-algebra and I be a subset of X, then I is called d-ideal of X if it satisfies the following conditions:
(1)
$$0 \in I$$
0 ∈ I
(2)
$$x *y\in I$$
x
∗ y ∈ I
and
$$y \in I \Rightarrow x \in I$$
y ∈ I ⇒ x ∈ I
(3)
$$x \in I$$
x ∈ I
and
$$y \in X \Rightarrow x *y \in I$$
y ∈ X ⇒ x
∗ y ∈ I
(i.e.)
$$I *X \subseteq I$$
I
∗ X ⊆ I
.

FormalPara.Para:

( X ,
∗ , 0 )
be a d-algebra and
$$x \in X$$
x ∈ X
. Define
$$x *X = \{x *a \mid a\in X\}$$
x

∗ a ∣ a ∈ X }
. X is said to be edge d-algebra if for any
$$x \in X, ~x *X = \{x, 0\}$$
x ∈ X ,
x
∗ X = { x , 0 }

FormalPara.Para:
([2, Lemma 2.8]) Let
$$(X, *, 0)$$
( X ,

be an edge d-algebra, then
$$x *0 = x$$
x

for any
$$x \in X$$

$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$

Section1.Para:
In this section we introduce the notion of
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation of d-algebra and give some examples and results.

Notation For any x, y in a d-algebra
$$(X, *, 0)$$
( X ,
∗ , 0 )

$$x*y$$
x
∗ y

$$x \wedge y = y(yx)$$
x ∧ y = y ( y x )
.

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 3.1
FormalPara.Para:
A mapping
$$\alpha $$
α
of a d-algebra X into itself is called an endomorphism if
$$\alpha (x*y) = \alpha (x) * \alpha (y)$$
α ( x
∗ y ) = α ( x )
∗ α ( y )
. Note that
$$\alpha (0) =0$$
α ( 0 ) = 0
.

FormalPara.Heading: Remark 3.1
FormalPara.Para:
Let X be an edge d-algebra and
$$\alpha $$
α
be an endomorphism on X. Then
$$\alpha (x)0 = \alpha (x)$$
α ( x ) 0 = α ( x )
for any
$$x \in X$$
x ∈ X

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 3.2
FormalPara.Para:
Let X be a d-algebra. A map
$$g : X \longrightarrow X$$
g : X ⟶ X
is a left-right derivation (briefly, (l, r) -derivation ) of X, if it satisfies the identity
$$g(xy) = g(x)y \wedge xg(y)$$
g ( x y ) = g ( x ) y ∧ x g ( y )
for all
$$x, y \in X$$
x , y ∈ X
. If g satisfies the identity
$$g(xy) = xg(y) \wedge g(x)y$$
g ( x y ) = x g ( y ) ∧ g ( x ) y
for all
$$x, y \in X$$
x , y ∈ X
, then g is a right–left derivation (briefly, (r, l) -derivation) of X. Moreover, if g is both a (l, r)- and (r, l)-derivation, then g is a derivation of X.

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 3.3
FormalPara.Para:
Let X be a d-algebra. A map
$$g : X \longrightarrow X$$
g : X ⟶ X
is called a left–right
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation (briefly, (l, r) -
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation ) of X, if it satisfies the identity
$$g(xy) = g(x)\alpha (y) \wedge \beta (x)g(y)$$
g ( x y ) = g ( x ) α ( y ) ∧ β ( x ) g ( y )
for all
$$x, y \in X$$
x , y ∈ X
. If g satisfies the identity
$$g(xy) = \alpha (x)g(y) \wedge g(x)\beta (y)$$
g ( x y ) = α ( x ) g ( y ) ∧ g ( x ) β ( y )
for all
$$x, y \in X$$
x , y ∈ X
, then g is called a right–left
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation (briefly, (r, l) -
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation) of X. Moreover, if g is both a (l, r)- and (r, l)-
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation, then g is an
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation of X.

FormalPara.Heading: Definition 3.7
FormalPara.Para:
Let X be a d-algebra and
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
be an
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation of X. An ideal I of X is said to be an
$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal (resp.
$$\beta $$
β
-ideal) if
$$\alpha (I)\subseteq I$$
α ( I ) ⊆ I
(resp.
$$\beta (I)\subseteq I$$
β ( I ) ⊆ I
).

$$X=\{0,a,b\}$$

$$\alpha $$
α
and

β
on X as follows
Then it is easy to check that X is a d-algebra,
$$I=\{0,b\}$$
I = { 0 , b }
is both an
$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal and
$$\beta $$
β
-ideal of X.

$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$

$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}(I)\subseteq I$$

( α , β )
( I )

( α , β )
( I )
=
{
g
( α , β )

∣ x ∈ I }
.

$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$

( α , β )

$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$

$$I=\{0,1,2\}$$

$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal,
$$\beta $$
β
-ideal and also a
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
-invariant of X.

FormalPara.Heading: Example 3.6
FormalPara.Para:
Let
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
be an (r, l)-
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation on X which described in Example 3.2, and let
$$I=\{0,a\}$$
I = { 0 , a }

$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal, but I is not an
$$\beta $$
β

$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
-invariant of X.

FormalPara.Heading: Theorem 3.7
FormalPara.Para:
Let X be a d-algebra, I be an d-ideal of X and
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
be a (r, l)-
$$(\alpha ,\beta )$$
( α , β )
-derivation of X. Then
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
is regular if and only if every
$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal of X is
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
-invariant.

FormalPara.Heading: Proof
FormalPara.Para:
Let I be an
$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal of a d-algebra X,
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
is regular and suppose that
$$y\in g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}(I)$$
y ∈
g
( α , β )
( I )
. Then for some
$$x\in I$$
x ∈ I
we have
$$y=g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}(x)$$
y =
g
( α , β )
( x )
, so by Lemma 3.1 we get
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}(x)\le \alpha (x)$$
g
( α , β )
( x )
≤ α
( x )
which implies that
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}(x) \alpha (x)=0\in I$$
g
( α , β )
( x )
α
( x )
= 0 ∈ I
. Note that
$$\alpha (x)\in \alpha (I)\subseteq I$$
α ( x ) ∈ α ( I ) ⊆ I
and hence
$$y\in I$$
y ∈ I
. Thus
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}(x)\subseteq I$$
g
( α , β )
( x )
⊆ I
, proving that I is a
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
-invariant.

Conversely, suppose that every
$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal of X is a
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
-invariant, we know that the zero ideal are both
$$\alpha $$
α
-ideal and
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
-invariant, so we get,
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}({0})\subseteq {0}$$
g
( α , β )
( 0 )
⊆ 0
and hence
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}(0)=0$$
g
( α , β )
( 0 )
= 0
which implies that
$$g_{(\alpha ,\beta )}$$
g
( α , β )
is regular.
